title: China Eximbank contributes $265 million to syndicated buyer’s credit loan for Phase 2 of Nam Ou Hydropower Project (Linked to Project ID#67486, ID#73303, ID#98809)
description: On August 31, 2015, Powerchina Resources Ltd. and the Government of Laos signed a Franchise Agreement and Power Purchase Agreement for Phase 2 of the Nam Ou Hydropower Project in Beijing. Then, in September 2015, Powerchina Resources Ltd. created a wholly-owned subsidiary and special purpose vehicle called the Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. in order to finance, develop, implement, and operate Phase 2 of the Nam Ou Hydropower Project on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis. The total cost of Phase 2 was $1.644 billion and it was financed with a mix of debt and equity.   Then, on September 8, 2016, Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. signed a $1.3 billion syndicated buyer’s credit loan agreement with China Development Bank, China Eximbank, and China Construction Bank. CDB contributed $770 million (captured in Project ID#67486) and China Eximbank and China Construction Bank jointly contributed $530 million (captured in Project ID#73301 & ID#98809). The loan carries a 20 year maturity. Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. also purchased buyer’s credit insurance from Sinosure. Additionally, Powerchina Resources Ltd. made a $340 million equity contribution to the project (captured in Project ID#73303).   The purpose of Phase 2 was to construct four hydropower stations — the 180MW Nam Ou 1 hydropower station, the 210MW Nam Ou 3 hydropower station, the 132MW Nam Ou 4 hydropower station, and 210MW Nam Ou 7 hydropower station — on the Nam Ou River in Luangprabang Province and Phongsaly Province. Upon completion, Nam Ou 1 will have a total reservoir capacity of 1.18 × 108 million cubic meters and generate 180MW from four sets of turbines and generators. Nam Ou 3 will have a total reservoir capacity of 218 million cubic meters and generate 210MW from three turbo-generator sets. Nam Ou 4 will have a total reservoir capacity of 142 million m3 and produce electricity from three turbo-generators with a total capacity of 132MW. Nam Ou 7 will include two turbo-generators sets with a total capacity of 210MW.   The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 1 are 20.0883°N 102.265379°E.  The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 3 are 20.695251°N 102.665404°E.  The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 4 are 21.120153°N 102.494173°E.  The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 7 are 21.120153°N 102.494173°E.   PowerChina Kunming Engineering Corp Ltd is the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. A project commencement ceremony was held on April 28, 2016. Then, China Eximbank conducted an on-site, post-loan project inspection on August 31, 2019. On December 26, 2019, a ceremony to start the first power generation unit was held. The Nam Ou 3 and 4 hydropower stations successfully passed 72-hour trial operations on August 31, 2020 and September 7, 2020, respectively. Phase 2 was originally expected to reach completion in 2020. The 1st, 3rd, and 4th stages received certificates of completion from the Laos government on April 28, 2021. On September 15th, 2021, the first unit of the seventh-level hydropower station on the Nam Ou River in Laos has successfully entered into a 72-hour trial operation, marking that all power stations in the Nam Ou River basin have achieved the power generation target and will start the period of joint commissioning and transportation. The Nam Ou River Power Plant was completed on September 29, 2021 with a live ceremony to commemorate its completion. Under the terms of a concession agreement with the Government of Laos, Powerchina Resources Ltd. has agreed to transfer the Phase 2 project to the Government of Laos after 29 years of operation. CDB also financed Phase 1 of the Nam Ou Hydropower Project (see Project ID#63762).
staff_comments: 1. The project is also known as the Nam Oucasgade Phase II Hydropower Project, the Nam Ou Second Phase Hydroelectric Power Project, the 616MW Nam Ou 1, 3, 4, and 7 Cascade Project, and the Nam Ou Phase II Hydropower Project. 2. The Chinese project title is 南欧江二期项目.  The Lao project title is ເຂື່ອນໄຟຟ້າ ນ້ຳອູ 1 and ເຂື່ອນໄຟຟ້າ ນ້ຳອູ 3 and ເຂື່ອນໄຟຟ້າ ນ້ຳອູ 4 and ເຂື່ອນໄຟຟ້າ ນ້ຳອູ 7. 3. In the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020, it identifies the face value of the CDB loan that supported this project as $1 biillion and the commitment year of the loan as 2011. However, official sources indicate the CDB issued a $660 million loan in 2016. 4. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020. 5. Some sources refer to Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. as a wholly owned subsidiary of Powerchina Resources Ltd., while others claim that Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. is jointly owned by Powerchina Resources Ltd. (990%) and EDL-Gen (10%). This issue merits further investigation. 6. Some sources refer to an 1156 MW Nam Ou Hydropower Station Project or an 1156 Nam Ou River Basin Hydropower Project — worth $2 billion to $2.7 billion — with seven separate cascade power stations and a total installed capacity of 1,272 MW or 1,156 MW. However, these are references to the larger project that comprises Phase I 540MW Nam Ou 2, 5, 6 Cascade Project (captured in Project ID#63762) and the Phase II 616MW Nam Ou 1, 3, 4, and 7 Cascade Project (captured in Project ID#67486).7. The individual financial contributions of CCB and China Eximbank to the syndicated loan are unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes equal financial contributions ($265,000,000) by dividing their joint contribution ($530,000,000) by those two members' of the loan syndicate.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank contributes $265 million to syndicated buyer’s credit loan for Phase 2 of Nam Ou Hydropower Project (Linked to Project ID#67486, ID#73303, ID#98809)

# Description
On August 31, 2015, Powerchina Resources Ltd. and the Government of Laos signed a Franchise Agreement and Power Purchase Agreement for Phase 2 of the Nam Ou Hydropower Project in Beijing. Then, in September 2015, Powerchina Resources Ltd. created a wholly-owned subsidiary and special purpose vehicle called the Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. in order to finance, develop, implement, and operate Phase 2 of the Nam Ou Hydropower Project on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis. The total cost of Phase 2 was $1.644 billion and it was financed with a mix of debt and equity.   Then, on September 8, 2016, Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. signed a $1.3 billion syndicated buyer’s credit loan agreement with China Development Bank, China Eximbank, and China Construction Bank. CDB contributed $770 million (captured in Project ID#67486) and China Eximbank and China Construction Bank jointly contributed $530 million (captured in Project ID#73301 & ID#98809). The loan carries a 20 year maturity. Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. also purchased buyer’s credit insurance from Sinosure. Additionally, Powerchina Resources Ltd. made a $340 million equity contribution to the project (captured in Project ID#73303).   The purpose of Phase 2 was to construct four hydropower stations — the 180MW Nam Ou 1 hydropower station, the 210MW Nam Ou 3 hydropower station, the 132MW Nam Ou 4 hydropower station, and 210MW Nam Ou 7 hydropower station — on the Nam Ou River in Luangprabang Province and Phongsaly Province. Upon completion, Nam Ou 1 will have a total reservoir capacity of 1.18 × 108 million cubic meters and generate 180MW from four sets of turbines and generators. Nam Ou 3 will have a total reservoir capacity of 218 million cubic meters and generate 210MW from three turbo-generator sets. Nam Ou 4 will have a total reservoir capacity of 142 million m3 and produce electricity from three turbo-generators with a total capacity of 132MW. Nam Ou 7 will include two turbo-generators sets with a total capacity of 210MW.   The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 1 are 20.0883°N 102.265379°E.  The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 3 are 20.695251°N 102.665404°E.  The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 4 are 21.120153°N 102.494173°E.  The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 7 are 21.120153°N 102.494173°E.   PowerChina Kunming Engineering Corp Ltd is the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. A project commencement ceremony was held on April 28, 2016. Then, China Eximbank conducted an on-site, post-loan project inspection on August 31, 2019. On December 26, 2019, a ceremony to start the first power generation unit was held. The Nam Ou 3 and 4 hydropower stations successfully passed 72-hour trial operations on August 31, 2020 and September 7, 2020, respectively. Phase 2 was originally expected to reach completion in 2020. The 1st, 3rd, and 4th stages received certificates of completion from the Laos government on April 28, 2021. On September 15th, 2021, the first unit of the seventh-level hydropower station on the Nam Ou River in Laos has successfully entered into a 72-hour trial operation, marking that all power stations in the Nam Ou River basin have achieved the power generation target and will start the period of joint commissioning and transportation. The Nam Ou River Power Plant was completed on September 29, 2021 with a live ceremony to commemorate its completion. Under the terms of a concession agreement with the Government of Laos, Powerchina Resources Ltd. has agreed to transfer the Phase 2 project to the Government of Laos after 29 years of operation. CDB also financed Phase 1 of the Nam Ou Hydropower Project (see Project ID#63762).
justification: Primary purpose is renewable energy generation through hydropower stations
evidence: Construction of four hydropower stations with total capacity of 732MW, renewable energy focus, long-term operation agreement

title: China Eximbank provides $23.7 million loan for the Sendin Water Treatment Plant Project (Linked to Project ID#64712)
description: In 2016, China Eximbank provided a $23,750,000 loan to Nakhonluang Water Supply Enterprise — a special purpose vehicle that is owned by Asia Investment, Development and Construction Sole Co., Ltd. — for the Sendin Water Treatment Plant Project. The loan reportedly carried a 3.6% interest rate and 20 year maturity. The project, which was implemented on a Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT), involved the construction of a water supply system in the village of Saendin within Naxaythong (Naxay Thong) District. More specifically, it involved the construction of intake from the Nam Ngum River, the construction of a water treatment plant with the capacity of 20,000 m3 /day, and the construction of clear water tanks (2 elevated tanks).   Project implementation commenced on June 17, 2016, and ended on June 2, 2018. Upon completion, the project reportedly delivered piped water from the water treatment plant to 56 villages in Naxaythong (Naxay Thong) District and 8 villages in Xaythany District.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Saendin Water Treatment Plant Project and the Sendine Water Treatment Plant Project. Asia Investment, Development and Construction Sole Co., Ltd owns a 50 year concession on the Saendin Water Treatment Plant.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
China Eximbank provides $23.7 million loan for the Sendin Water Treatment Plant Project (Linked to Project ID#64712)

# Description
In 2016, China Eximbank provided a $23,750,000 loan to Nakhonluang Water Supply Enterprise — a special purpose vehicle that is owned by Asia Investment, Development and Construction Sole Co., Ltd. — for the Sendin Water Treatment Plant Project. The loan reportedly carried a 3.6% interest rate and 20 year maturity. The project, which was implemented on a Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT), involved the construction of a water supply system in the village of Saendin within Naxaythong (Naxay Thong) District. More specifically, it involved the construction of intake from the Nam Ngum River, the construction of a water treatment plant with the capacity of 20,000 m3 /day, and the construction of clear water tanks (2 elevated tanks).   Project implementation commenced on June 17, 2016, and ended on June 2, 2018. Upon completion, the project reportedly delivered piped water from the water treatment plant to 56 villages in Naxaythong (Naxay Thong) District and 8 villages in Xaythany District.
justification: Project focuses on water supply and sanitation infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of water treatment plant and supply system, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides loan for Sekong 2 Substation Transmission & Transformation Project
description: On September 8, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Laos signed a loan agreement for the Sekong 2 Substation Transmission & Transformation Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to at least partially finance a $317 million EPC contract between Electricite Du Laos and Pinggao Group Co Ltd (a subsidiary of State Grid Corporation of China), which was signed on December 17, 2015.   The purpose of the project is to construct or expand seven 500kV/230kV and 230 kV/115 kV substations, including the Tonpheung transformer substation and the Huayxay substation. It also involves the construction of seven 230 kV and 115 kV transmission lines, including a 48-km transmission line from Huayxay to Tonpheung.   Pinggao Group Co Ltd is the general (EPC) contractor responsible for implementation. However, PowerChina Hubei Engineering Co., Ltd and China Energy Engineering Group Guangdong Electric Power Design Institute Co., Ltd (GEDI) are also involved in project design and implementation.   There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for the Sekong 2 Substation Transmission & Transformation Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. Laos’ gross foreign exchange reserves were dangerously low between 2019 and 2021, hovering between 1.4 and 2.3 months of import cover, and total public and publicly-guaranteed (PPG) debt increased from 68 percent of GDP ($12.5 billion) in 2019 to 88 percent in 2021 of GDP (or $14.5 billion). According to a report published by the World Bank in April 2022, ‘[t]he energy sector, mostly represented by Électricité du Laos (EDL), accounted for over 30 percent of total PPG debt in 2021. […] EDL’s debt service obligations [were] still unsustainable [at the time], with future debt service accounting for about two fifths of EDL’s total operating revenue.’ The Laotian authorities sought and secured debt service payment deferrals from their Chinese creditors in 2020 and 2021; according to the World Bank, ‘[d]ebt service deferrals granted by major lenders in 2020-2021 amounted around 3.6 percent of GDP in 2021’ and ’[a]s a result, actual debt service payments are estimated to have declined to 48 percent of total revenues in 2021, compared to 65 percent in the 2021 [Government of Laos] plan.’  The country’s central bank (Bank of the Lao P.D.R) also made a $300 million drawdown under its currency swap agreement with the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) in June 2020 — when its gross reserves stood at only 1.5 months of import cover and credit rating agencies warned of a high default probability. Then, in 2021, the short-term emergency loan from the PBOC was ‘rolled over’ for another year. Around the same time, a Chinese state-owned enterprise purchased a major public infrastructure asset in Laos—a large part of the country’s electricity transmission grid—from EDL as part of an apparent debt-for-equity swap. China Southern Power Grid Co. and EDL established a joint venture known as Électricité du Laos Transmission Company Limited (EDLT) in September 2020.  China Southern Power Grid Co. purchased a 90% ownership stake in EDLT in exchange for a $600 million fee (equity infusion). Then, in March 2021, EDLT signed a 25-year concession agreement, which made it responsible for management of the country’s high-voltage transmission network above 230 kilovolts. Independent observers suggested at the time that EDL would likely use the $600 million upfront payment from China Southern Power Grid Co. to service its outstanding debts to Chinese creditors, although this has not been independently confirmed. According to the World Bank’s International Debt Statistics, the Government of Laos was responsible for making average annual debt service payments to Chinese creditors worth $232 million between 2019 and 2019 and average annual debt service payments to Chinese creditors worth $60 million between 2020 and 2021 (a substantially lower figure due to payment deferrals); however, it expected to make average annual debt service payments to Chinese creditors worth nearly $678 million over the next seven years (2022-2028).
staff_comments: 1. This project is sometimes transliterated from Chinese as Sigma Hydropower Station-Segon 2nd Substation Power Transmission and Transformation Project. 2. The Chinese project title is 西格玛水电站-色贡二变电站输变电项目 or 老挝色贡2变电站至西格玛水电站输变电项目. 3. This project was possibly funded through a preferential buyer’s credit or buyer’s credit loan, both of which typically finance 85% of the cost of a commercial (EPC) contract (85% of $317 million). The estimated face value of the loan is $269.45 million. However, this issue merits further investigation.4. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides loan for Sekong 2 Substation Transmission & Transformation Project

# Description
On September 8, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Laos signed a loan agreement for the Sekong 2 Substation Transmission & Transformation Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to at least partially finance a $317 million EPC contract between Electricite Du Laos and Pinggao Group Co Ltd (a subsidiary of State Grid Corporation of China), which was signed on December 17, 2015.   The purpose of the project is to construct or expand seven 500kV/230kV and 230 kV/115 kV substations, including the Tonpheung transformer substation and the Huayxay substation. It also involves the construction of seven 230 kV and 115 kV transmission lines, including a 48-km transmission line from Huayxay to Tonpheung.   Pinggao Group Co Ltd is the general (EPC) contractor responsible for implementation. However, PowerChina Hubei Engineering Co., Ltd and China Energy Engineering Group Guangdong Electric Power Design Institute Co., Ltd (GEDI) are also involved in project design and implementation.   There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for the Sekong 2 Substation Transmission & Transformation Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. Laos’ gross foreign exchange reserves were dangerously low between 2019 and 2021, hovering between 1.4 and 2.3 months of import cover, and total public and publicly-guaranteed (PPG) debt increased from 68 percent of GDP ($12.5 billion) in 2019 to 88 percent in 2021 of GDP (or $14.5 billion). According to a report published by the World Bank in April 2022, ‘[t]he energy sector, mostly represented by Électricité du Laos (EDL), accounted for over 30 percent of total PPG debt in 2021. […] EDL’s debt service obligations [were] still unsustainable [at the time], with future debt service accounting for about two fifths of EDL’s total operating revenue.’ The Laotian authorities sought and secured debt service payment deferrals from their Chinese creditors in 2020 and 2021; according to the World Bank, ‘[d]ebt service deferrals granted by major lenders in 2020-2021 amounted around 3.6 percent of GDP in 2021’ and ’[a]s a result, actual debt service payments are estimated to have declined to 48 percent of total revenues in 2021, compared to 65 percent in the 2021 [Government of Laos] plan.’  The country’s central bank (Bank of the Lao P.D.R) also made a $300 million drawdown under its currency swap agreement with the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) in June 2020 — when its gross reserves stood at only 1.5 months of import cover and credit rating agencies warned of a high default probability. Then, in 2021, the short-term emergency loan from the PBOC was ‘rolled over’ for another year. Around the same time, a Chinese state-owned enterprise purchased a major public infrastructure asset in Laos—a large part of the country’s electricity transmission grid—from EDL as part of an apparent debt-for-equity swap. China Southern Power Grid Co. and EDL established a joint venture known as Électricité du Laos Transmission Company Limited (EDLT) in September 2020.  China Southern Power Grid Co. purchased a 90% ownership stake in EDLT in exchange for a $600 million fee (equity infusion). Then, in March 2021, EDLT signed a 25-year concession agreement, which made it responsible for management of the country’s high-voltage transmission network above 230 kilovolts. Independent observers suggested at the time that EDL would likely use the $600 million upfront payment from China Southern Power Grid Co. to service its outstanding debts to Chinese creditors, although this has not been independently confirmed. According to the World Bank’s International Debt Statistics, the Government of Laos was responsible for making average annual debt service payments to Chinese creditors worth $232 million between 2019 and 2019 and average annual debt service payments to Chinese creditors worth $60 million between 2020 and 2021 (a substantially lower figure due to payment deferrals); however, it expected to make average annual debt service payments to Chinese creditors worth nearly $678 million over the next seven years (2022-2028).
justification: Project focuses on electricity transmission and substation infrastructure, which supports both renewable and non-renewable energy distribution
evidence: Construction of seven substations and transmission lines, including 500kV/230kV and 230kV/115kV infrastructure

title: Chinese Government provides grant — through Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Fund — for China-Laos Poverty Reduction Cooperation Community Demonstration Project (Linked to Project ID#49339)
description: On November 13, 2014, the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation (LMC) mechanism was established at the 17th China-ASEAN Summit. On March 23, 2016, the Chinese Government established the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Fund, through which China pledged to provide $300 million over 5 years to 5 countries along the Mekong River -- Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam -- to fund small and medium sized cooperation projects (as captured via Project ID#49339). The Chinese Government subsequently provided grant funding through the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Fund for the China-Laos Poverty Reduction Cooperation Community Demonstration Project. The purpose of the project was to undertake a set of community development activities — including agro-business demonstration, improvements of small-scale public infrastructure and environment, and capacity building activities — in Thadokkham village within Xaythany District and Vientiane Municipality. Guangxi Foreign Capital Poverty Reduction Project Management Center and International Poverty Reduction Center in China (IPRCC) cooperated with the Department of Rural Development and Cooperatives of the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry of Laos to implement the project.   The project, which was undertaken between 2016 and 2020, built 13 steel frame greenhouses, cultivated 26 vegetable planting demonstration households, planted 15 hectares of organic rice, cultivated 27 planting demonstration households, organized 3 technical trainings on rainproof cultivation of organic vegetables and standardized rice planting for 60 villagers. The second phase of the project built 10 additional steel frame greenhouses with water facilities and paved gravel roads (production roads), carried out technical training for 100 persons on greenhouse organic vegetable planting, provided daily planting technical guidance, built a new village activity center and supported relevant facilities. A total of 46 vegetable planting demonstration households were cultivated, with an annual income of more than RMB 10000 per household, driving 64 farmers to plant vegetables on the land around the greenhouse.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant — through Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Fund — for China-Laos Poverty Reduction Cooperation Community Demonstration Project (Linked to Project ID#49339)

# Description
On November 13, 2014, the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation (LMC) mechanism was established at the 17th China-ASEAN Summit. On March 23, 2016, the Chinese Government established the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Fund, through which China pledged to provide $300 million over 5 years to 5 countries along the Mekong River -- Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam -- to fund small and medium sized cooperation projects (as captured via Project ID#49339). The Chinese Government subsequently provided grant funding through the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Fund for the China-Laos Poverty Reduction Cooperation Community Demonstration Project. The purpose of the project was to undertake a set of community development activities — including agro-business demonstration, improvements of small-scale public infrastructure and environment, and capacity building activities — in Thadokkham village within Xaythany District and Vientiane Municipality. Guangxi Foreign Capital Poverty Reduction Project Management Center and International Poverty Reduction Center in China (IPRCC) cooperated with the Department of Rural Development and Cooperatives of the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry of Laos to implement the project.   The project, which was undertaken between 2016 and 2020, built 13 steel frame greenhouses, cultivated 26 vegetable planting demonstration households, planted 15 hectares of organic rice, cultivated 27 planting demonstration households, organized 3 technical trainings on rainproof cultivation of organic vegetables and standardized rice planting for 60 villagers. The second phase of the project built 10 additional steel frame greenhouses with water facilities and paved gravel roads (production roads), carried out technical training for 100 persons on greenhouse organic vegetable planting, provided daily planting technical guidance, built a new village activity center and supported relevant facilities. A total of 46 vegetable planting demonstration households were cultivated, with an annual income of more than RMB 10000 per household, driving 64 farmers to plant vegetables on the land around the greenhouse.
justification: Project focuses on poverty reduction and community development through agricultural and infrastructure improvements, without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Community development activities, agro-business demonstration, small-scale public infrastructure improvements, capacity building, poverty reduction focus

However, these are references to the larger project that comprises Phase I 540MW Nam Ou 2, 5, 6 Cascade Project (captured in Project ID#63762) and the Phase II 616MW Nam Ou 1, 3, 4, and 7 Cascade Project (captured in Project ID#67486).7. The individual financial contributions of CCB and China Eximbank to the syndicated loan are unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes equal financial contributions ($265,000,000) by dividing their joint contribution ($530,000,000) by those two members' of the loan syndicate.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
CCB contributes $265 million to syndicated buyer’s credit loan for Phase 2 of Nam Ou Hydropower Project (Linked to Project ID#67486, ID#73303, & ID#73301)

# Description
On August 31, 2015, Powerchina Resources Ltd. and the Government of Laos signed a Franchise Agreement and Power Purchase Agreement for Phase 2 of the Nam Ou Hydropower Project in Beijing. Then, in September 2015, Powerchina Resources Ltd. created a wholly-owned subsidiary and special purpose vehicle called the Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. in order to finance, develop, implement, and operate Phase 2 of the Nam Ou Hydropower Project on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis. The total cost of Phase 2 was $1.644 billion and it was financed with a mix of debt and equity.   Then, on September 8, 2016, Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. signed a $1.3 billion syndicated buyer’s credit loan agreement with China Development Bank, China Eximbank, and China Construction Bank. CDB contributed $770 million (captured in Project ID#67486) and China Eximbank and China Construction Bank jointly contributed $530 million (captured in Project ID#73301 and ID#98809). The loan carries a 20 year maturity. Nam Ou Power Co., Ltd. also purchased buyer’s credit insurance from Sinosure. Additionally, Powerchina Resources Ltd. made a $340 million equity contribution to the project (captured in Project ID#73303).   The purpose of Phase 2 was to construct four hydropower stations — the 180MW Nam Ou 1 hydropower station, the 210MW Nam Ou 3 hydropower station, the 132MW Nam Ou 4 hydropower station, and 210MW Nam Ou 7 hydropower station — on the Nam Ou River in Luangprabang Province and Phongsaly Province. Upon completion, Nam Ou 1 will have a total reservoir capacity of 1.18 × 108 million cubic meters and generate 180MW from four sets of turbines and generators. Nam Ou 3 will have a total reservoir capacity of 218 million cubic meters and generate 210MW from three turbo-generator sets. Nam Ou 4 will have a total reservoir capacity of 142 million m3 and produce electricity from three turbo-generators with a total capacity of 132MW. Nam Ou 7 will include two turbo-generators sets with a total capacity of 210MW.   The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 1 are 20.0883°N 102.265379°E.  The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 3 are 20.695251°N 102.665404°E.  The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 4 are 21.120153°N 102.494173°E.  The precise locational coordinates of Nam Ou 7 are 21.120153°N 102.494173°E.   PowerChina Kunming Engineering Corp Ltd is the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. A project commencement ceremony was held on April 28, 2016. Then, China Eximbank conducted an on-site, post-loan project inspection on August 31, 2019. On December 26, 2019, a ceremony to start the first power generation unit was held. The Nam Ou 3 and 4 hydropower stations successfully passed 72-hour trial operations on August 31, 2020 and September 7, 2020, respectively. Phase 2 was originally expected to reach completion in 2020. The 1st, 3rd, and 4th stages received certificates of completion from the Laos government on April 28, 2021. On September 15th, 2021, the first unit of the seventh-level hydropower station on the Nam Ou River in Laos has successfully entered into a 72-hour trial operation, marking that all power stations in the Nam Ou River basin have achieved the power generation target and will start the period of joint commissioning and transportation. The Nam Ou River Power Plant was completed on September 29, 2021 with a live ceremony to commemorate its completion. Under the terms of a concession agreement with the Government of Laos, Powerchina Resources Ltd. has agreed to transfer the Phase 2 project to the Government of Laos after 29 years of operation.  CDB also financed Phase 1 of the Nam Ou Hydropower Project (see Project ID#63762).
justification: Primary purpose is hydropower generation, a renewable energy source
evidence: Construction of four hydropower stations with total capacity of 732MW, renewable energy focus

title: Chinese Government delivers $500,000 grant — via World Food Program — to support Syrian refugees in Lebanon (Linked to Project ID#64588)
description: On September 14, 2016, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) issued a $500,000 grant to the United Nations World Food Program (WFP) in Lebanon to aid Syrian refugees. This grant was part of a larger $2 million grant commitment. The remaining $1.5 million was set aside for refugees in Jordan (see Project ID#64588).   The Chinese Ambassador to Lebanon signed an aid handover certificate on March 14, 2018. These funds reportedly supported 16,000 Syrian refugees in Lebanon. The donation consisted of water and canned food, and eligible refugees received an electronic card that allowed them to purchase food at 490 eligible stores in Lebanon. On April 19, 2018, the Chinese Ambassador to Lebanon Wang Kejian signed a document with WFP, which marked the official end of the emergency food aid project.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government delivers $500,000 grant — via World Food Program — to support Syrian refugees in Lebanon (Linked to Project ID#64588)

# Description
On September 14, 2016, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) issued a $500,000 grant to the United Nations World Food Program (WFP) in Lebanon to aid Syrian refugees. This grant was part of a larger $2 million grant commitment. The remaining $1.5 million was set aside for refugees in Jordan (see Project ID#64588).   The Chinese Ambassador to Lebanon signed an aid handover certificate on March 14, 2018. These funds reportedly supported 16,000 Syrian refugees in Lebanon. The donation consisted of water and canned food, and eligible refugees received an electronic card that allowed them to purchase food at 490 eligible stores in Lebanon. On April 19, 2018, the Chinese Ambassador to Lebanon Wang Kejian signed a document with WFP, which marked the official end of the emergency food aid project.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian aid and social development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Emergency food aid for Syrian refugees, distribution through World Food Program, no energy or infrastructure components

title: Chinese Government donates 42 cars, 370 office computers, 200 laptops, 70 printers, and 70 cameras
description: On June 16, 2016, the Council of Ministers of Lebanon approved a proposed Chinese Government donation of equipment for use by a designated set of Lebanese government ministries, directorates and municipalities. Then, on March 16, 2017, the Chinese Government handed over a batch of office equipment and vehicles to the Lebanese Council for Development and Reconstruction (CDR). The donation consisted of 42 cars, 370 office computers, 200 laptops, 70 printers, and 70 cameras. The aid was expected to improve the Lebanese Government's office conditions and efficiency. Chinese Ambassador to Lebanon Wang Kejian and President of CDR Nabil El-Jisr signed the project handover certificate on behalf of their respective governments the same day.
staff_comments: This project is known as the Equipment and Vehicle Project. The Chinese project title is 黎巴嫩政府物资项目.'Year uncertain' box has been checked because while the Council of Ministers of Lebanon approved this donation on June 16, 2016, this does not represent the date that the Government of Lebanon and the Government of China signed an agreement for this donation; that event likely occurred prior to the Lebanese Government's formal approval of the agreement, and did not necessarily occur in 2016.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government donates 42 cars, 370 office computers, 200 laptops, 70 printers, and 70 cameras

# Description
On June 16, 2016, the Council of Ministers of Lebanon approved a proposed Chinese Government donation of equipment for use by a designated set of Lebanese government ministries, directorates and municipalities. Then, on March 16, 2017, the Chinese Government handed over a batch of office equipment and vehicles to the Lebanese Council for Development and Reconstruction (CDR). The donation consisted of 42 cars, 370 office computers, 200 laptops, 70 printers, and 70 cameras. The aid was expected to improve the Lebanese Government's office conditions and efficiency. Chinese Ambassador to Lebanon Wang Kejian and President of CDR Nabil El-Jisr signed the project handover certificate on behalf of their respective governments the same day.
justification: Project involves donation of office equipment and vehicles to improve government operations, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 42 cars, 370 office computers, 200 laptops, 70 printers, and 70 cameras for government use

title: 15th batch of Chinese peacekeeping force is sent to Lebanon (Linked to #41114)
description: On May 13, 2017, the 15th batch of Chinese peacekeepers completed its rotation in Lebanon as part of the UN Interim Forces In Lebanon (UNIFIL). The group consisted of 410 soldiers and was deployed in the border area of ​​southern Lebanon next to Israel for tasks related to mine clearance and detonation, border pile planting, engineering, construction and maintenance, and humanitarian relief for a period of one year.  China has sent UNFIL peacekeeping forces to Lebanon every year from 2006 to 2020. The program was temporarily suspended due to COVID-19 on June 30, 2020, but reinstated in August 2020 to respond to the Beirut explosion. See project ID #41114 for the full project. For individual project descriptions, see these projects: 1st batch: #67581; 2nd batch: #67578; 3rd batch: #67580; 4th batch #71863; 5th batch #71869; 6th batch: #41110; 7th batch: #67582; 8th batch: #67584; 9th batch: #67587; 10th batch: #67588; 11th batch: #67579; 12 batch: #71901; 13th batch: #67589; 14th batch: #72070; 15th batch: #72071; 16th batch: #66366; 17th batch: #67576; 18th batch: #67574; 19th batch: #72082.

# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
15th batch of Chinese peacekeeping force is sent to Lebanon (Linked to #41114)

# Description
On May 13, 2017, the 15th batch of Chinese peacekeepers completed its rotation in Lebanon as part of the UN Interim Forces In Lebanon (UNIFIL). The group consisted of 410 soldiers and was deployed in the border area of ​​southern Lebanon next to Israel for tasks related to mine clearance and detonation, border pile planting, engineering, construction and maintenance, and humanitarian relief for a period of one year.  China has sent UNFIL peacekeeping forces to Lebanon every year from 2006 to 2020. The program was temporarily suspended due to COVID-19 on June 30, 2020, but reinstated in August 2020 to respond to the Beirut explosion. See project ID #41114 for the full project. For individual project descriptions, see these projects: 1st batch: #67581; 2nd batch: #67578; 3rd batch: #67580; 4th batch #71863; 5th batch #71869; 6th batch: #41110; 7th batch: #67582; 8th batch: #67584; 9th batch: #67587; 10th batch: #67588; 11th batch: #67579; 12 batch: #71901; 13th batch: #67589; 14th batch: #72070; 15th batch: #72071; 16th batch: #66366; 17th batch: #67576; 18th batch: #67574; 19th batch: #72082.
justification: Project focuses on peacekeeping and humanitarian efforts without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Mine clearance, border pile planting, engineering, construction, maintenance, and humanitarian relief activities

title: Chinese Government dispatches 11th Medical Team to Motebang Hospital (Linked to #55769)
description: Since 1997, Hubei Province has been sending medical teams to Lesotho. In 2016, the Chinese Government dispatched the 11th Chinese medical team to Lesotho. The team was stationed at Motebang Hospital, which is located on Mandela Road in the town of Hlotse within Leribe District. The 8-member team completed its term of service between October 13, 2016 and October 13, 2017. The team carried out more than 800 operations treated 15,000 patients, and conducted 14 free clinics in remote areas. It also donated medicines and equipment to Lesotho (captured in #55769).
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 11th Medical Team to Motebang Hospital (Linked to #55769)

# Description
Since 1997, Hubei Province has been sending medical teams to Lesotho. In 2016, the Chinese Government dispatched the 11th Chinese medical team to Lesotho. The team was stationed at Motebang Hospital, which is located on Mandela Road in the town of Hlotse within Leribe District. The 8-member team completed its term of service between October 13, 2016 and October 13, 2017. The team carried out more than 800 operations treated 15,000 patients, and conducted 14 free clinics in remote areas. It also donated medicines and equipment to Lesotho (captured in #55769).
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services and medical assistance without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team providing healthcare services, conducting operations, and treating patients
